question_details.query: What are the most effective management practices on farmland for increasing butterfly and moth abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The most effective farmland management practices for increasing butterfly and moth abundance include: 1) Planting nectar flower mixture/wildflower strips (Action ID: 3932) - these provide essential nectar sources and habitat, with studies showing higher species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths compared to conventional field margins, cropped fields, or grass-only margins. 2) Converting to organic farming (Action ID: 3907) - organic farms show greater species richness and abundance of butterflies and burnet moths compared to conventional farms, with abundance increasing with time since conversion. 3) Increasing or maintaining natural/semi-natural habitat in the farmed landscape (Action ID: 3910) - farms with greater proportions of semi-natural habitat or woodland in surrounding areas support higher species richness and abundance. 4) Planting grass buffer strips/margins (Action ID: 3982) - particularly wider margins (up to 6m) and floristically enhanced grass buffers show higher abundance and species richness compared to cropped field edges. 5) Delaying cutting or grazing dates (Action ID: 3967) - grasslands cut once in July or September rather than May/June show greater abundance of butterflies and burnet moths. 6) Using rotational mowing (Action ID: 3966) - grasslands with staggered mowing or rotational management have higher species richness and abundance compared to annual full-site mowing. 7) Leaving unsprayed conservation headlands (Action ID: 3898) - these show greater species richness and abundance of butterflies compared to sprayed headlands. 8) Creating uncultivated margins (Action ID: 3981) - longer or wider uncultivated margins that are not cut, or only cut in spring/autumn, support higher species richness and abundance compared to summer-cut margins.
summary_statements: Planting nectar flower mixture or wildflower strips provides essential nectar sources and habitat for butterflies and moths.

question_details.query: What are the alternative management strategies to prescribed burning for maintaining open grassland habitats for butterflies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Alternative management strategies to prescribed burning for maintaining open grassland habitats for butterflies include rotational mowing, changing mowing regimes, grazing management, mechanical vegetation removal, and herbicide application. Rotational mowing (mowing strips in alternate years or leaving some areas uncut) can increase butterfly species richness and abundance compared to annual complete mowing. Delaying cutting dates to July or September rather than May/June can increase butterfly abundance. Changing mowing regimes (such as mowing in August vs November) can maintain caterpillar populations. Grazing management shows mixed results - intensive grazing generally reduces butterfly abundance compared to light or no grazing, while traditional low-intensity grazing can be beneficial. Mechanical removal of mid-storey or ground vegetation and herbicide application are additional alternatives, though evidence for their effectiveness specifically for butterflies is limited. Maintaining species-rich semi-natural grasslands through extensive management (light grazing or annual mowing) can support butterfly communities.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits of retaining or restoring habitat connectivity for butterfly populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies have documented several benefits of habitat connectivity for butterfly populations. Retaining connectivity between habitat patches helps butterfly populations persist, with well-connected low quality habitat patches more likely to retain Alcon large blue populations than less well connected patches. Habitat corridors also facilitate movement, as common buckeye butterflies were more likely to colonize distant habitat patches when released on corridors of suitable habitat. Restoring or creating habitat connectivity has been shown to increase the abundance of multiple butterfly species, including Karner blue, high brown fritillary, small pearl-bordered fritillary, marsh fritillary, and regal fritillary butterflies. Connected habitat patches also promote movement between patches, with common buckeye and variegated fritillary butterflies more likely to move between connected than unconnected patches. Grassland strips providing nectar or shelter were more likely to be used by butterfly species than strips with no resources.

question_details.query: Which grassland management techniques in UK agricultural settings are most beneficial for increasing butterfly and moth abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Multiple UK studies demonstrate that reducing management intensity on permanent grasslands significantly benefits butterfly and moth populations. Key techniques include: 1) Rotational mowing - cutting strips in alternate years or leaving rotational areas uncut increases butterfly and burnet moth abundance compared to annual complete mowing, with two heath fritillary populations surviving on rotationally mown grasslands while six went extinct on unmanaged grasslands; 2) Delayed cutting - mowing grassland once in July instead of May/June increases butterfly abundance and species richness, with September cutting maintaining stable scarce large blue butterfly populations while May mowing led to decreases over time; 3) Reducing fertilizer and chemical inputs - unfertilized UK grasslands support greater species richness of specialist moths and similar abundance of adult butterflies compared to fertilized grasslands; 4) Altering mowing regimes on road verges and greenspaces - less frequent mowing or leaving areas unmown increases butterfly species richness and abundance compared to regularly mown areas. These findings are supported by evidence that 24 out of 58 moth species prefer less intensively managed UK grasslands, and reducing grazing combined with stopping chemical applications increased both species richness and total abundance of large moths.

question_details.query: What are the benefits for butterflies and moths of reducing or eliminating chemical inputs on farmland?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Reducing or eliminating chemical inputs on farmland provides significant benefits for butterflies and moths. Studies found that areas managed with less frequent, reduced, or no pesticide, herbicide, fertilizer, or unspecified chemical inputs had greater species richness of adult butterflies and moths, or caterpillars, compared to areas with more frequent or conventional chemical applications (action 3897). Similarly, arable field margins and rice field banks that were not sprayed with herbicides like glyphosate had greater species richness and higher abundance of butterflies than sprayed areas (action 3896). Converting to organic farming also showed benefits, with seven of eleven studies finding that organic farms had greater species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths than conventionally managed farms (action 3907). These benefits included not only overall increases in butterfly and moth populations, but also specific species preferences for unfertilized or lightly fertilized grasslands over heavily fertilized ones.

question_details.query: What are some evidence-based alternatives to prescribed burning for managing disturbance in forests to benefit butterflies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence-based alternatives to prescribed burning for managing forest disturbance to benefit butterflies include: (1) Thinning trees within forests - studies in the USA and Finland found that coniferous woodland which had been thinned, along with other management practices, had greater species richness and abundance of butterflies compared to unmanaged woodland. (2) Clearing or opening patches in forests - 14 studies across multiple countries found that cleared patches had greater species richness and abundance of butterflies than unmanaged patches or closed canopy forest, benefiting species such as chequered blue, woodland brown, high brown fritillary and small pearl-bordered fritillary. (3) Coppicing woodland - 10 studies found that coppiced woodland had higher abundance of butterflies generally, and species such as heath fritillary specifically, compared to unmanaged woodland, with optimal benefits occurring 2-7 years after coppicing. (4) Creating young plantations within mature woodland - one UK study found that woodlands with larger areas of young plantations helped pearl-bordered fritillary and small pearl-bordered fritillary populations persist longer than in mature woodland.

What management actions for traditional orchards and vineyards in the USA and Germany have been studied for their effects on butterflies and moths?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Management actions for traditional orchards and vineyards in the USA and Germany have been studied with the following findings:

For traditional orchards: Two studies evaluated maintaining traditional orchards for butterflies and moths, one in the USA and one in Germany. The German study found managed orchards had similar species richness but lower abundance of butterflies and burnet moths compared to abandoned orchards, and similar community composition between managed and abandoned orchards. The USA study found unmanaged and partially managed orchards had greater species richness and diversity of leaf-eating arthropods (including caterpillars) than commercially managed orchards.

For vineyard management: Two studies evaluated managing vineyards for butterflies and moths, one in the USA and one in Spain. The USA study found grass strips between vine rows had greater butterfly species richness than vine rows themselves, and vineyards with fewer chemicals had greater butterfly species richness than conventionally managed vineyards. Another USA study found vineyards managed to encourage native plants with rare insecticide use had greater butterfly abundance than conventionally managed vineyards.

For chemical reductions: Eleven studies evaluated reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use generally, with two studies each in the USA and Germany. These found that orchards, crop edges, farms, vineyards and agricultural landscapes managed with reduced or no chemical inputs had greater species richness and abundance of adult butterflies and moths, or caterpillars, compared to conventional chemical applications.

For organic farming: Thirteen studies evaluated converting to organic farming, including one study in Germany. Seven of eleven studies found organic farms had greater species richness of butterflies and moths than conventional farms, and seven of eleven studies found organic farms had greater abundance of butterflies and moths than conventional farms.

question_details.query: In European grasslands, which grazing management strategies appear most beneficial for butterfly species richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the evidence from action documents, several grazing management strategies show beneficial effects for butterfly species richness in European grasslands:

Reducing grazing intensity by lowering stocking density appears to be one of the most beneficial strategies. Five of eight replicated studies in the UK, Sweden, Germany, USA and Switzerland found that grasslands grazed with lower stocking densities of sheep, cattle or mixed livestock had greater species richness of adult butterflies, all moths and burnet moths compared to higher stocking densities (Action 3959).

Seasonal removal of livestock also shows benefits for butterfly richness. Two of three controlled studies in the UK found that grasslands where cattle or sheep were removed during summer months had similar or greater species richness of butterflies compared to continuously grazed grasslands (Action 3960).

Rotational grazing demonstrates positive effects with two of four studies in France and USA finding that rotationally grazed grasslands had greater species richness of butterflies and burnet moths than continuously grazed grasslands, though results varied by stocking density and study duration (Action 3965).

Changing livestock type can also benefit butterfly richness, with studies in Sweden and France finding that semi-natural grasslands grazed by cattle or horses had greater species richness of butterflies and burnet moths than sheep-grazed grasslands (Action 3963).

Conversely, increasing grazing intensity or cutting frequency generally shows negative effects, with studies finding lower species richness and abundance of butterflies in intensively grazed sites compared to low or no grazing (Action 3962).

Ceasing grazing entirely produces mixed results - some studies show increased butterfly richness after 4-10 years of abandonment, while others show similar or reduced richness compared to grazed grasslands (Action 3956).

Beyond sowing wildflower mixes, what alternative management practices for field margins and headlands have been shown to benefit butterfly populations on UK farmland?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Research has shown several alternative management practices for field margins and headlands that benefit butterfly populations on UK farmland beyond sowing wildflower mixes. Conservation headlands (leaving headlands unsprayed) have been shown to increase both butterfly species richness and abundance compared to sprayed headlands, with studies finding greater species richness of butterflies and higher abundance of butterflies and caterpillars in unsprayed headlands. Hedgerow management practices, including planting new hedges and managing existing hedgerows for wildlife, have demonstrated significant benefits. Planting new hedges has been found to result in higher species richness of butterflies and macro-moths compared to crops or pasture, with higher abundance of butterflies, moths and gatekeepers along hedgerows. Managing hedgerows through cutting regimes (cutting once every 2-3 years or in autumn rather than winter) has shown higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths, with hedgerows containing trees supporting higher butterfly abundance than simple hedgerows. Creating uncultivated margins around fields has shown benefits including higher species richness of butterflies in longer or wider margins and higher abundance of butterflies compared to cereal fields. Grass buffer strips planted around fields have been found effective when they are wider (up to 6m wide), with floristically enhanced grass buffers showing greater species richness and abundance of butterflies than standard grass margins. Leaving uncropped, cultivated margins can increase butterfly abundance in some species, while buffer strips to reduce pesticide run-off have been shown to increase moth abundance compared to conventionally managed margins. Proper cutting management of these margins (cutting only in spring or autumn rather than summer) results in higher species richness and abundance of butterflies.

question_details.query: What does the evidence show about the timeframe for butterfly and moth population response to woodland coppicing or clearing?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence shows that butterfly and moth populations respond to woodland coppicing and clearing over various timeframes. For coppicing, studies found that abundance was higher in woodland coppiced 2-4 years ago compared to older coppice (5-11 years or >15 years). One study found that woodland coppiced 2 years ago had greater butterfly species richness than woodland coppiced >15 years ago. For clearing patches in forests, one study found that patches cleared 2-4 years ago had greater abundance of heath fritillary butterflies than patches cleared 7-11 years ago or patches in their first year after clearance. Another study reported that butterfly species richness declined over the first three years after clearing, but abundance initially increased before declining. The evidence suggests that populations typically respond positively 2-4 years after management, but responses can vary by species and decline as vegetation ages beyond this timeframe.

question_details.query: Besides planting field margins, what are some alternative actions to increase habitat heterogeneity within agricultural fields for butterflies and moths?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several alternative actions can increase habitat heterogeneity within agricultural fields for butterflies and moths. Reducing field size or maintaining small fields has been shown to increase both species richness and abundance of butterflies and burnet moths compared to landscapes with larger fields (Action ID: 3974). Creating beetle banks - raised strips within arable fields - can increase micro-moth species richness and abundance compared to conventionally managed field margins (Action ID: 3927). Planting new hedges within agricultural landscapes provides habitat with higher species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths compared to crop fields or pasture (Action ID: 3976). Leaving unharvested crop headlands within arable fields can create habitat with greater butterfly species richness and abundance than harvested crops (Action ID: 3924). Leaving uncropped, cultivated margins or plots within fields can increase butterfly abundance, particularly when managed under agri-environment schemes (Action ID: 3923). Planting wildflower strips or nectar flower mixtures within fields significantly increases both species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths compared to conventional field margins or cropped fields (Action ID: 3932). Finally, increasing overall crop diversity across the farmed landscape, while showing mixed results, represents another approach to creating habitat heterogeneity within agricultural systems (Action ID: 3921).

question_details.query: In US prairies, how do different management techniques like grazing, mowing (haying), and prescribed burning compare in their effects on butterfly abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on studies in US prairies, prescribed burning has mixed effects on butterfly abundance compared to other management techniques. Three studies found that prairies managed by haying had higher abundance of prairie specialist butterflies than prairies managed by burning (Action IDs: 3945, 3882). Prairies managed by burning had lower abundance of two prairie specialists (regal fritillary and arogos skipper) compared to prairies managed by haying (Action ID: 3882). However, prairies managed by burning had higher abundance of generalist and migrant species compared to hayed prairies. For rotational burning, four replicated studies found that prairies burned more than 1-4 years ago had higher total abundance of prairie specialist, grassland, and all butterflies compared to prairies burned more recently (Action ID: 3883). The abundance of regal fritillary was higher in rotationally burned prairies four years after the last burn compared to one or eight years after burning. Grazing combined with rotational burning showed variable results, with some studies finding higher abundance in grazed areas compared to burned areas, while others found similar or lower abundance depending on the specific butterfly species examined (Action ID: 3908).

summary_details.relevant_summary: Within European agri-environment schemes, the habitat creation options most consistently shown to increase butterfly and moth abundance are planting nectar flower mixtures or wildflower strips, and managing hedgerows to benefit wildlife. Wildflower strips consistently demonstrated higher butterfly and moth abundance across multiple studies, with 10 out of 23 studies showing significantly higher abundance compared to conventional field margins or cropped fields. Hedgerow management involving less frequent cutting (every 2-3 years or in autumn) and maintaining complex structure also consistently increased butterfly and moth abundance. Other interventions such as creating uncultivated margins and planting wild bird seed mixtures showed more variable results, with some evidence of benefits but less consistent effects across studies.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of managing perennial crop systems such as orchards, vineyards, and coffee plantations for butterfly and moth conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from perennial crop systems shows several management practices can benefit butterfly and moth conservation. In coffee plantations, shade-grown systems support higher species richness of caterpillars compared to sun-grown monocultures (action 3931), and farms with mixed native and non-native tree species show higher butterfly diversity than those with single non-native species (action 3920). In vineyards, grass strips between vine rows and reduced chemical management increase butterfly species richness compared to conventional management (action 3919), while maintaining ground cover can reduce leafhopper pests and increase natural enemy abundance (action 1395). For traditional orchards, the evidence is mixed, with one German study finding similar species richness but lower abundance of butterflies and burnet moths in managed versus abandoned orchards (action 3917). Diversifying ground vegetation and canopy structure around woody crops increases reptile diversity and abundance in olive groves (action 3526), though the direct effects on butterflies and moths are not documented in the available evidence.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken to manage agricultural field boundaries to improve their value for butterfly and moth conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several management actions for agricultural field boundaries have been shown to benefit butterfly and moth conservation. Planting grass buffer strips or margins around arable or pasture fields is highly effective, with 26 studies showing that wider margins (up to 6m) and floristically enhanced grass buffers or wildflower strips increase both species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths compared to conventional margins. Managing hedgerows specifically for wildlife is another key action, with 17 studies demonstrating that hedgerows cut less frequently (every 2-3 years), cut in autumn rather than winter, or managed to allow incremental growth support higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths compared to annually cut hedgerows. Planting new hedges also benefits butterflies and moths, with 7 studies showing established hedgerows have higher species richness and abundance than crop fields or pasture. Rice field banks can be managed by avoiding mowing and herbicide application, which one study found increased butterfly species richness and abundance. Creating uncultivated margins around intensive fields can be beneficial depending on management, with 10 studies showing that margins which are not grazed or cut, or only cut in spring or autumn, have higher species richness and abundance of butterflies than those cut in summer. The evidence shows that boundary management practices which reduce disturbance, increase floristic diversity, and provide structural complexity are most beneficial for butterfly and moth conservation.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken along transportation and service corridors to benefit butterfly and moth populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies have shown that several management practices along transportation corridors can benefit butterfly and moth populations. Restoring or maintaining species-rich grassland along road verges and railway lines has been found to increase both the richness and abundance of butterflies and moths compared to verges dominated by non-native vegetation. Wide road verges have higher butterfly richness and abundance than narrow verges. Altering mowing regimes by mowing less frequently or later in summer can increase butterfly and moth species richness and abundance, while also reducing butterfly mortality from traffic. Stopping the use of herbicides on road verges has been shown to increase butterfly species richness and abundance compared to verges dominated by non-native weeds where herbicides are used. The specific actions supported by evidence include reducing or eliminating herbicide use, sowing native wildflowers and larval food plants, maintaining wider verges, and implementing less frequent or later-season mowing schedules.

question_details.query: What are the effects of reducing or ceasing pesticide and fertiliser use on butterfly and moth diversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Reducing or ceasing pesticide and fertiliser use generally increases butterfly and moth diversity and abundance, based on evidence from multiple studies. Eight of eleven studies found that areas with reduced or no chemical inputs (pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers) had greater species richness of butterflies and moths compared to conventionally managed areas. Six studies also found higher abundance of these insects in areas with reduced chemical inputs. Specific findings include: unsprayed field headlands had greater species richness and abundance of butterflies than sprayed headlands; organic farms generally had greater species richness and abundance of butterflies, burnet moths, and macro-moths compared to conventional farms (though some studies found no difference or effects were limited to certain landscape contexts); and arable margins not sprayed with herbicide glyphosate had greater species richness and butterfly abundance than sprayed margins. The positive effects varied by species, with some moths showing preferences for unfertilized grasslands while others preferred fertilized areas.

question_details.query: What are the main alternatives to grazing for maintaining open grassland habitats, and how do their effects on butterfly communities compare?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The main alternatives to grazing for maintaining open grassland habitats include mowing/cutting, prescribed burning, rotational mowing, and mechanical cutting/scrub clearing. 

Mowing regimes show mixed effects on butterflies. Prairies managed by haying had higher abundance of prairie specialist butterflies but lower abundance of generalist and migrant butterflies compared to burned prairies. The abundance of prairie specialists was higher in the first year after haying than in the second year, and Karner blue butterflies showed similar abundance on mowed and burned savannas.

Prescribed burning shows varied effects on different butterfly species. Some studies found higher abundance of heath fritillary adults, marsh fritillary caterpillar webs, and Fender's blue caterpillars and eggs on burned lands compared to unburned or grazed areas, while other studies found lower abundance of Brenton blue butterfly eggs and adults, rosy marsh moth caterpillars, and regal fritillary adults on burned lands. Prairies managed by burning had lower abundance of prairie specialists like regal fritillary and arogos skipper compared to hayed prairies, but higher abundance of generalist and migrant species.

Rotational mowing appears beneficial for butterfly communities. Studies found greater species richness and abundance of butterflies in grasslands managed with rotational mowing techniques compared to complete annual mowing. European reviews indicated that rotationally mowing grassland benefitted 27 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern.

Mechanical cutting/scrub clearing shows positive effects, with studies finding higher abundance of Karner blue butterflies on mechanically cut pine barrens compared to rotationally burned areas, and higher species richness and abundance of butterflies under power lines managed by mechanical cutting compared to unmanaged land.
